Tech humour

One can do that

When the emails could only be sent 500 miles (approximately).

How Macs got graphing software (I checked the New York Times page mentioned - and the folks named in the story are likewise named in NY Times as responsible for the graphing software).

I tried to do a fizzbuzz using modern web platform apis and im terrified that it actually works pic.twitter.com/SUaYVZAu8j

— laura (@freezydorito) December 19, 2020</blockquote>

Fizzbuzz was something someone devised as a basic “Can you do basic programming?” test - that got a lot of attention via the blog of the co-founder of Stack Overflow. Yes, this StackOverflow - anyhow taking the solution via JavaScript from Stack Overflow (if one satisfies the CORS restrictions) works apparently!

Excel

Person 1: The glass is 1/2 full

Person 2: The glass is 1/2 empty

Excel: The glass is the 1st of February

— Andrew R (@ExcelPope) October 16, 2021</blockquote>

In America of course the glass is the 2nd of January!

Interviews

OH, on technical interviews: “if I saw a live-ass engineer at my company hand-rolling a linked list I’d parachute right the fuck on in to figure out why they’ve gone all historical re-enactment on company time”

— Tess Rinearson (@_tessr) December 5, 2020</blockquote>

Confused folks

Kafka?

I moderate /r/kafka and people often mistake for a subreddit about the programming language. Our users have almost spontaneously developed their own way for dealing with this confusion. 😭😭😭😭😭😭 pic.twitter.com/W2fguNVXcd

— Elizabeth Holmes Feminist (@LitAnscombe) September 28, 2021</blockquote>

PS2? PS/2?

Honestly, the students from around 2000/2001 at Uni right now are doomed…

One asked me two years ago when he just started at uni "What did you use before USB? Was there no mouse or keyboard? Were they hardwired?" I told him we used PS2 "What? Did you hook up a PS2 controller?"

— Jan Andreasen | ❤️ EVE (@andreasen_jan) April 29, 2022</blockquote>

Not front-end?

Thinking about the time my mom, curious about my job, asked how the "rear-end development" is going

— Rebecca (Slatkin) Sloane (@RebeccaSlatkin) March 25, 2022</blockquote>

Rapid development?

Reasons to not trust the new iPhone:
- It was developed very quickly
- We don't know its long-term side effects
- It is not FDA approved
- It has a microchip
- I don't know how it will fit in my veins

— joey alison sayers (@joeyalison) September 12, 2021</blockquote>

This is a fork (of Jekyll Netlify Boilerplate that is maintained by Dan Urbanowicz).
